photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02413.jpg
photos.title: Striated Frogfish
photos.description: Frogfish can inhale their prey in six thousands of a second. That's one of the fastest eating methods known in the animal kingdom.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01009-Edit.jpg
photos.title: Hawksbill Sea Turtle
photos.description: The tapered head of a hawksbill ends in a sharp point resembling a bird's beak, hence its name.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC03105.jpg
photos.title: Broadclub Cuttlefish
photos.description: Cuttlefish have three hearts! One that pumps blood around the body and two pumping blood to the gills.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02717-Edit.jpg
photos.title: Blue-Ringed Octopus
photos.description: The blue-ringed octopus flashes its 50-60 rings within a third of a second as a warning display to predators. Being one of the world's most venomous marine animals, its poison causes total body paralysis - also to humans.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02196.jpg
photos.title: Purple-Edged Ceratosoma
photos.description: Identification of sea slugs are often difficult. The keys to identification in this case is the broken purple rigde together with the placement of the three mantle lobes on both sides of the body. One lobe on either side of the head, one on the side of the gills, and one between those two.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC00158.jpg
photos.title: Gorgonian Coral
photos.description: Raja Ampat's biodiversity is the richest in the world and 75% of all known coral species can be found there.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01953.jpg
photos.title: Balloonfish
photos.description: The large dragon-like eyes help this nocturnal hunter forage for food during the night-hours. Their eye pattern is a mesmerizing sight. A friend once compared it to a reflection of the universe.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02438.jpg
photos.title: Nudibranch
photos.description: A distinguishing feature of H. batangas is the fine network of lines on its dorsum. What a beauty!

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02160.jpg
photos.title: Bullock's Hypselodoris
photos.description: Nudibranchs are hermaphrodites - simultaneously both male and female. Reproducing still takes two to tango!

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02932-Edit-2.jpg
photos.title: Flambouyant Cuttlefish
photos.description: The flambouyant cuttlefish flashes its hypnotic color scheme and pulses its fins when approached, possibly to signal its toxicity to potential predators.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC00010.jpg
photos.title: Mushroom Coral Reticuludia
photos.description: There are over 3000 species of nudibranchs, and new ones are regularly found!

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01908-Edit.jpg
photos.title: Juvenile Longhorn Cowfish
photos.description: This fish moves by oscillating its tail fin very rapidly, creating a hover-like appearance when swimming.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC09757.jpg
photos.title: Nudibranch
photos.description: The term nudibranch is derived from the Greek words nudus and brankhia, meaning 'naked' and 'gill' respectively. The flower-like protrusions on the back are the exposed (naked) gills.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02981.jpg
photos.title: Skeleton Shrimp
photos.description: The rear legs are used to hook itself to plants where it lives, in this case a bryozoan. Front claws are used for hunting and moving around.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02231.jpg
photos.title: Striped Poison-Fang Blenny Mimic
photos.description: The strait of Lembeh is littered with garbage, but not all discarded stuff is bad for the creatures living there. An old bottle can be the safest place for a blenny to live.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01059.jpg
photos.title: Broadclub Cuttlefish
photos.description: Cuttlefish are able to change the color of their skin in an instant using a set of astonishing ten million individually controlled color cells.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01148.jpg
photos.title: Ribboned Sweetlips
photos.description: This species is certainly named after their protruding fat sweet lips.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01395.jpg
photos.title: Bigeye Trevally
photos.description: This fast-swimming predator can grow up to 120 cm long and form schools numbering more than 1500 individuals.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02312.jpg
photos.title: Nudibranch
photos.description: Some nudibranchs are adapted to resemble small pieces of soft coral.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02121.jpg
photos.title: Red-Lined Jorunna
photos.description: A key feature for the Red-Lined Jorunna is its length of up to 20 cm. That's an enormous size for a nudibranch.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC00808.jpg
photos.title: Fluted Giant Clam
photos.description: The giant clam produces its hard shell with help from zooxanthellae, an algea that grows within the shell valve.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01139.jpg
photos.title: Ribboned Sweetlips
photos.description: Groups of sweetlips often hang tucked between layers of coral, which allowed me to experiment a bit with lighting.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01548.jpg
photos.title: Bluestripe and Golden-lined Snappers
photos.description: The goatfish (Mulloidichthys mimicus) is part of a weird relationship with the bluestripe snapper where it mimics its colors to look almost exactly the same. The reason for that is not entirely clear, but the goatfish is presumably a more preferred prey than the bluestrip snapper. So there may be some goatfish in the fish ball as well.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01413.jpg
photos.title: Oceanic Manta Ray
photos.description: The majestic oceanic manta is a pelagic species, using the ocean currents to travel. Sites with high availability of zooplankton, such as the nutrient-rich waters of Raja Ampat, attracts them closer to the reefs to feed.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01956.jpg
photos.title: Balloonfish
photos.description: The balloonfish can inflate its body three times the normal size to make attacks more difficult for predators.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC01182.jpg
photos.title: Clown Anemonefish
photos.description: When anemonefish leaves it host for a long time, they need to re-adapt to the host stinging cells. To do so, the fish goes through a dance-like ritual taking several hours. Clownfish rarely move more than 30 cm from their host anemone, though.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02240.jpg
photos.title: Bobbit Worm
photos.description: Little is known about the behaviour of bobbit worms. It's theorized that the worm doesn’t see at all but uses its excellent receptors to detect movement in the water to sense nearby fish.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC00763.jpg
photos.title: Ornate Ghost Pipefish
photos.description: Ornates adopt the coloration of the environment it settles in after its larval stage.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02861-Edit.jpg
photos.title: Spiny Devilfish
photos.description: While this genus is typically buried in the sand or perfectly camouflaged in coral rubble, they can sometimes be found crawling on the seabed using their pectoral fins as legs.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02650.jpg
photos.title: Harlequin Swimming Crab
photos.description: This crab lives in symbiosis with tube dwelling anemones where it takes cover to hide from predators.

photos.name: 2019-indo-DSC02068.jpg
photos.title: Ornate Ghost Pipefish
photos.description: The ghost pipefish camouflages very well in coral reefs, and spend a lot of time floating - almost like a slow moving leaf - with its mouth pointed downwards.

photos.name: DSC09167.jpg
photos.title: Reef Manta Ray
photos.description: By swimming against the tidal current, mantas sieves zooplankton from the water. They are the only type of ray evolved to filter feed.

photos.name: DSC02949.jpg
photos.title: Starry Grouper
photos.description: Groupers typically have large mouths, fat lips and stout bodies. The starry grouper is relatively small, but still fearless enough to stay still and stare back when I was snapping a shot.

photos.name: DSC07959.jpg
photos.title: Indian Lionfish
photos.description: Active at night, this fish will follow you and exploit your dive light to find prey.

photos.name: DSC00591.jpg
photos.title: Green Turtle
photos.description: Surprisingly curious, this young turtle swam around us in the shallows during our way out to the Salt Pier, a gorgeous dive site on Bonaire.

photos.name: DSC04037.jpg
photos.title: Southern Stingray
photos.description: The flat body has sharp corners and allows the stingray to efficiently bury itself in the sand to avoid predators.

photos.name: DSC07445.jpg
photos.title: SS Thistlegorm
photos.description: Sunk during a surprise attack by a pair of German Heinkel He-111 bomber planes in World War II. The ship is over 400 feet long, and most of its cargo is still present in, or around the wreck.

photos.name: DSC08044.jpg
photos.title: Pygmy Sweepers
photos.description: These fish feed on zooplankton at night. During daytime, they are usually found in shaded areas, such as inside wrecks, caves and under overhangs. They often form dense schools in these shelters.

photos.name: DSC00208.jpg
photos.title: Common Starfish
photos.description: In addition to having the ability to regenerate limbs, most sea stars are able to eat outside of their bodies by moving its stomach inside the prey to ingest it.

photos.name: DSC08605.jpg
photos.title: Pyjama Nudibranch
photos.description: Sponges are popular food source for nudibranchs. The slugs incorporate the color from what they eat to their tissue color as camouflage. This beautiful pair have found a toxic finger-sponge (Negombata magnifica) to feed on. They won't be harmed, and instead use the chemicals to reduce the chance of being eaten.

photos.name: DSC06417.jpg
photos.title: Elphinstone Anthias
photos.description: Participating in a huge feeding aggregation, the massive amount of anthias make some of the visually dramatic scenes on the reef. Anthias live in harems consisting of one dominant male, a few lesser males, juveniles and a cluster of females. All anthias are hermaphrodites and begin life as female.

photos.name: DSC02397.jpg
photos.title: Scalloped Hammerhead Shark
photos.description: All of our dives on Cocos featured hammerheads, most shy and in the distance like here. One of my best memories from Cocos was the ascent on a site called Manuelita, which we dove many times. What we didn't realize at first was that the hammerheads had disperged and moved away when we got there. Immediately when we started to ascend they returned. During our safety stop we saw the hoards coming from all directions and reuniting at the cleaning stations on the ocean floor.

photos.name: DSC03660.jpg
photos.title: Chamberlain's Nembrotha
photos.description: Nudibranch's eyes are located inside the body and measure about a quarter of a millimeter in diameter. These simple eyes are only coarsly able to discern differences in light intensity.

photos.name: DSC09197.jpg
photos.title: Gracile Lizardfish
photos.description: Lizardfish are frequent visitors of sandy or muddy areas and lie sometimes partly buried on the sea floor.

photos.name: DSC03543.jpg
photos.title: Giant Frogfish
photos.description: Frogfish don't have swim bladders. Instead they walk on the ocean floor using their non-traditional fins.

photos.name: DSC03638.jpg
photos.title: Scalloped Hammerhead Shark
photos.description: Sharks can detect electrical fields created by other animals using specialized sensory organs. For the hammerheads, these organs are spread over the oddly wide-shaped head to boost the sensitivity.

photos.name: DSC00266.jpg
photos.title: False Clown Anemonefish
photos.description: Clownfish hatch near the surface and travel deeper to search for a host anemone when they reach their juvenile stage. Within a clownfish community there is a strict hierarchy where juveniles begin at the bottom and have to gradually move upwards by proving their abilities to the rest of the population. During this time they may be victims to agression, and possibly eviction from the anemone by more mature clownfish.

photos.name: DSC00366.jpg
photos.title: Lumpsucker
photos.description: Instead of having the normal type of pelvic fins (below), this fish has evolved disc-like fins and use them to adhere to the substrate.

photos.name: DSC07517.jpg
photos.title: Norton 16H Motorcycles
photos.description: More than 100 motorcycles were aboard the SS Thistlegorm before it sunk. Many of them are still there.

photos.name: DSC06604.jpg
photos.title: The Dugongs of Marsha Shouna
photos.description: Dugongs are believed to be inspirations behind tales of mermaids and in parts of Indonesia they are considered reincarnations of women. The word "dugong" means lady of the sea. It's herbivorous and feed uniquely on sea grass. Their numbers are very low and in some countries they are entirely depleted due to hunting, bycatch and habitat destruction. I was extremely lucky to encounter one in Marsha Shouna on the western coast of the Red Sea, once home to thousands of dugongs but now with very few individuals. The 100 km coastline along Marsa Alam had only seven dugongs left at the time of writing.

photos.name: DSC08266.jpg
photos.title: SS Carnatic
photos.description: A diver explores the wreck of SS Carnatic, which broke in half after hitting the reef near Shadwan Island. 31 people drowned.

photos.name: DSC03018.jpg
photos.title: Whitetip Reef Shark
photos.description: The large oval eyes allow the whitetip to see well in dim light.

photos.name: DSC03808.jpg
photos.title: Nudibranch
photos.description: Many nudibranchs use their brightly colored bodies to warn potential predators that they are full of distasteful chemicals. This is an alternative defence mechanism to having a hard shell, which most other molluscs use as primary protection.

photos.name: DSC04577.jpg
photos.title: Magnificent Sea Anemone
photos.description: The previous name for this anemone was the Ritteri Anemone, updated to Heteractis magnifica, or "Magnificent Sea Anemone". Perhaps so because it's too beautiful for the first dull name. The anemone can entirely retract it's tentacles. It's column, here in purple color, will then be exposed. On the matter of reproducing this anemone can do it both sexually and asexually - it can actually clone itself.

photos.name: DSC00946.jpg
photos.title: Green Turtle
photos.description: The fat beneath the carapace of a C. Mydas is green, which is why it's common name is "green turtle".

photos.name: DSC08936.jpg
photos.title: Reef Manta Ray
photos.description: The Maldives is home to around 5000 manta rays - the largest group of manta rays in the world.

photos.name: DSC07393.jpg
photos.title: Locomotive Engine
photos.description: Two Stanier 8F locomotive engines, part of the SS Thistlegorm's cargo, sunk together with the ship. Both locomotives are separated from the wreck.

photos.name: DSC00792.jpg
photos.title: Fuchsia Flatworm
photos.description: Flatworms lack circulatory and respiratory organs (such as gills), and respiration is performed by diffusion through the worm's entire surface. They are somewhat similar to nudibranchs in appearance, but the similarity is only superficial. It's easy to distinguish them by the lack of antennas/rhinophores, that they generally move faster and are flat - obviously.

photos.name: DSC01136.jpg
photos.title: Atlantic Tarpon
photos.description: A group of tarpons accompanied us during our night dives on Bonaire. These nocturnal hunters exploited the light from our torches to find prey.

photos.name: DSC02379.jpg
photos.title: Tiger Shark
photos.description: The tigers have excellent sense of smell and sight. Some native Hawaiians think their eyeballs have the power to look into the future.

photos.name: DSC03044.jpg
photos.title: Whitetip Reef Shark
photos.description: The whitetip sharks let me close enough to get slapped by their caudal fins.

photos.name: DSC02594.jpg
photos.title: Juvenile Boxfish
photos.description: The members of the boxfish family display a unique behavior of blowing into the sand of the sea floor to uncover buried food, such as tasty worms and shrimps. The boxfish is one of those animals being consistently cute its entire lifetime, not just as juvenile.

photos.name: DSC03448.jpg
photos.title: Reticulate Stargazer
photos.description: Night dives at the Anilao pier feel like something from another world. The sandy bottom comes to life with all the crabs, shrimps, worms, slugs and bottom dwellers doing their brutal routine. Many of these animals feed at night, and the site turns to a large scale battlefield when the sun sets. A stargazer approached us in the midst of the chaos, landed on the sand and burrowed its tapered body, exposing only its big, heavy, flat head and a vertically slanted mouth. He waits for passing fish before jumping upwards while creating a vacuum to suck in the prey.

photos.name: DSC00157.jpg
photos.title: Toad Crab
photos.description: This decorator crab collects sea weed, sponges, algae and other particles in the water to improve its camouflage.

photos.name: DSC06687.jpg
photos.title: Spinner Dolphin
photos.description: Those times I'm lucky enough to hear whistles and clicking sounds I instantly change focus from finding small stuff, snails or whatever I'm up to at the moment, and instead scout for what could be dolphins. They are fast swimmers, so if they are around, they are not necessarily for long. Most often I will not find them, but sometimes I do, and some of these encounters I believe are the dolphins approaching me more than the other way around. They are curious, playful and intelligent creatures.

photos.name: DSC07308.jpg
photos.title: Reef Stonefish
photos.description: Motionless, this fish sometimes stay at the same site for several months. Not agressive, but will inject a venom if stepped on. It's the world's most venomous fish.

photos.name: DSC04665.jpg
photos.title: Devil Scorpionfish
photos.description: Normally, pectoral fins are used to swim but this fish has evolved two small stilts that allow it to walk and dig the seabed instead. While this is by no means unique for an ocean species, it's still fascinating to observe this type of irregularity. Perhaps, a long time ago another species did just the same, and that is why there are creatures (such as you and me) walking on land today.

photos.name: DSC01316.jpg
photos.title: The Hilma Hooker Wreck
photos.description: After losing power off the coast of Bonaire, The Hilma Hooker was towed to the island's main pier. As this ship already was suspected by the DEA, a search was quickly conducted and 11.000 kg of marijuana was found. The owner of the ship however, was not. Hilma Hooker was starting to wear down and the hull was in dire need of maintenance. It was towed a couple of kilometers south in fear of disrupting boat traffic in case it sunk, which it promtly did. Now it's a great dive site, easily accessible on the western coast of Bonaire.

photos.name: DSC06145.jpg
photos.title: St. Johns Cave Systems
photos.description: St. Johns is know for its array of caverns, tunnels, overhangs and swim-throughs. The sun pierce through the cracks, crevices and holes inside the caverns, guiding us through the maze. The majestetic area is like a forgotten world, mountains now covered in coral.

photos.name: Kris Krister 453.jpg
photos.title: Potato Cod
photos.description: This fish is bold. It may come really close and will sometimes tamper with your dive gear. It's latin name tukula means "man-eater" due to its large size, but it means no harm - it's just a curious and social fish.
photos.location: Cod Hole, Great Barrier Reef, Australia

photos.name: DSC01646.jpg
photos.title: Spotted Scorpionfish
photos.description: The scorpionfish is commonly found virtually invisible, blending in with the environment. Do not touch.

photos.name: DSC02648.jpg
photos.title: Chamberlain's Nembrotha
photos.description: Perhaps the most distinctive characteristic of nudibranchs is the pair of tentacles on the head, called rhinophores. They are chemical sensors used to smell and taste the chemicals dissolved in the water, such as food and potential mates. Many species of nudibranchs can retract these vital organs to protect them against other fish.

photos.name: DSC00564.jpg
photos.title: Spotted Moray Eel
photos.description: Unlike most fish who use suction to capture their prey, moray eels use two sets of jaws in their throats to drag prey inside their mouths.

photos.name: DSC01151.jpg
photos.title: Thresher Shark
photos.description: Malapascua is known for its legendary thresher sharks. They are usually found in deep waters, but when the sun starts to rise they ascend to the cleaning stations on the sloaps of Monad Shoal. Diving starts 05.00 am.

photos.name: DSC04854.jpg
photos.title: Arminid Nudibranch
photos.description: Nudibranchs have shells as larva, but shed them when they mature. Shells are heavy and make moving around difficult. Most molluscs use the shell as a primary defence, but nudibranchs have developed other techniques for protection, such as toxic secretion. A few make their own poisons, but most utilize the toxic metabolites from what they eat.

photos.name: DSC06693.jpg
photos.title: Spinner Dolphin
photos.description: Dolphins use echolocation to "see" the environment, similar to a sonar or radar. They send out bursts of clicking sounds, and based on the frequency of the return signal, and how much time the signal used to return, the dolphin can estimate what kind of objects are nearby.

photos.name: DSC02499.jpg
photos.title: Scalloped Hammerhead Shark
photos.description: The wide-set eyes give hammerheads long visual range, better than most sharks.

photos.name: DSC03330.jpg
photos.title: Coleman's Shrimp
photos.description: The pair of shrimp clears a little patch on the fire urchin with their claws. The patch is just large enough to move freely around collecting small pieces of food while still being protected from predators by the urchin's toxic spines. The largest of the shrimps is always the female.

photos.name: DSC04006.jpg
photos.title: Bullock's Hypselodoris
photos.description: Nudibranchs have external gills (the yellow rosette on the back), hence its name, which translates to "naked gill".

photos.name: DSC08755.jpg
photos.title: Juvenile Blacktip Reef Shark
photos.description: These, and many more, juvenile sharks were eager to become grown-up-sharks and tried to hunt small fish all day long. They didn't seem to mind me too much and allowed me to swim with them while they were hunting.

photos.name: DSC02984.jpg
photos.title: Painted Frogfish
photos.description: The social activity of this fish is rather limited, and the male will sometimes eat the female if she stays around too long after mating.

photos.name: DSC03425.jpg
photos.title: Bobbit Worm
photos.description: The bobbit is my favorite worm. It can grow up to a meter, has a stunning purple iridescence, five antennae to sense passing fish and a scissor-like mouth to split prey in half. Most of the body is covered in sand, just enough is exposed to ambush surprised fish. This worm is quite rare, shy, and mysterious.

photos.name: DSC00259.jpg
photos.title: False Clown Anemonefish
photos.description: Sea anemones are poisonous to most fish. The clownfish however is immune to their stinging tentacles and form a symbiotic relationship with the anemone where the clownfish receive protection from predators, and the anemone benefits from the clownfish' natural activity. For example, the wedging swimming movements from the clownfish stimulate water sirculation around its tentacles, increasing metabolism and growth.

photos.name: DSC07567.jpg
photos.title: Blackfin Barracuda
photos.description: Barracudas aggregate in schools as protection against larger predators.

photos.name: DSC06743.jpg
photos.title: Green Turtle
photos.description: It's believed that green turtles need between 20 - 50 years to reach sexual maturity, and a turtle's life is not easy so very few reach adulthood. Once, the estimate was one percent. It dropped to one thousandth. Previously suffering from unrestricted exploitation by humans, turtles are now having more like a global protection status. However, their slow reproductive rate, combined with increased development in coastal areas make the species very vulnerable. Many turtles are also lost due to accidental catch by fishermen.

photos.name: DSC07252.jpg
photos.title: Moon Jellyfish
photos.description: The short tentacles around the bell of the moon jelly are poisonous to small marine animals, which the jelly sometimes eat. A complete meal is ensured by using a layer of mucus covering the creature to catch plankton.

photos.name: DSC08097.jpg
photos.title: The Bow of Chrisoula K
photos.description: This cargo ship was headed for Jeddah packed with Italian tiles, but never made it.

photos.name: DSC01782.jpg
photos.title: Blackfin Barracuda
photos.description: A streamlined predator, very powerful with fearsome teeth. Its torpedo like body of almost pure muscle makes it extremely fast. A fascinating fish commonly seen schooling.

photos.name: DSC07475.jpg
photos.title: Red Sea Corals
photos.description: Water temperatures in the Red Sea peaks at 35 degrees celcius. Most reefs bleach and die off in such conditions while the Red Sea corals linger on. They are remarkably resilient to high temperatures. Scientists are trying to figure out the key to this crucial ability, with hope of some day be able to salvage reefs currently suffering from rising sea temperatures in other parts of the world.

photos.name: DSC02188.jpg
photos.title: Christmas Tree Worm
photos.description: This pair of feather-like tentacles, called radioles, is used for respiration and to catch floating plankton and microscopic plants. Each worm has one pair of these radioles.

photos.name: DSC04061.jpg
photos.title: Leopard Anemone Shrimp
photos.description: A rare, beautiful shrimp. It's name is derived from where it was found - the Izu Peninsula in Japan.

photos.name: DSC04222.jpg
photos.title: Graeffe's Sea Cucumber
photos.description: The sea cucumbers are scavengers, crawling mostly around the sea floor. Not always though - since their gametes float around in the water column a vertical positioning is thought to increase the chance of successful reproduction for both male and female.

photos.name: DSC00598.jpg
photos.title: Green Turtle
photos.description: The green turtles inhabit coastal areas of as many as 140 countries. The Caribbean Islands have one of the largest populations of green turtles in the world.

photos.name: DSC06574.jpg
photos.title: Tassled Scorpionfish
photos.description: An ambush predator that excels at blending in with the surroundings. Highly venomous.

photos.name: DSC02569.jpg
photos.title: Tube Dwelling Anemone
photos.description: Not a true anemone, this animal construct a tube in the sand in which it lives. The entire body, including more than 200 tapering tentacles, can be retracted inside the tube for protection.

photos.name: Kris Krister 276.jpg
photos.title: Dwarf Minke Whale
photos.description: In Australia, a group of whales circled us and gradually came closer for each round they took. As they moved closer we could recognize their fine details, their uniqueness and beauty. Scientists in Australia use the spots on their skin to distinguish them from each other and is the primary method used to count the number of individuals. We dove with all together five minke whales for almost two hours before they perished into the open sea. It was a once-in-a-lifetime experience I will never forget.
photos.location: Ribbon Reefs, Great Barrier Reef, Australia

photos.name: DSC03769.jpg
photos.title: Giant Frogfish
photos.description: In just two weeks, the frogfish can change its own color to match the environment. They generally do not move very much, but sometimes use the pelvic fins (the ones below the body) to walk along the sea floor. Their pectoral fins (one on each side) are used for stability.

photos.name: DSC04244.jpg
photos.title: Juvenile Longhorn Cowfish
photos.description: A peaceful fish having horns as defence to make it more difficult for predators to swallow it. The cowfishes are, sadly, a common target for the aquarium industry due to their adorable looks.

photos.name: DSC07737.jpg
photos.title: Silky Shark
photos.description: Once abundant in the world's oceans, now overfished and in some places depleted. The silky is the shark second most commonly taken as bycatch due to commercial fishing of tuna, it's favored prey.

photos.name: DSC01682.jpg
photos.title: Banded Coral Shrimp
photos.description: Prefers to live in caves, often seen upside down. Cleans parasites from fish cruising by.

photos.name: DSC02544.jpg
photos.title: Fire Urchin
photos.description: Often found in shallow areas, this type of urchin sometimes carpet the sandy floor in large aggregations. Having iridescent blue dots, radiant bodies and long spines, they contribute to brighten up the muddy coast of Anilao.

photos.name: DSC00692.jpg
photos.title: White Eyed Moray
photos.description: Moray eels are shy creatures usually seen peeking out from rocks and coral formations with only their heads exposed. Most of the long slender body is hidden inside crevices, where it retreats completely if you approach too fast or come too near.

photos.name: DSC07389.jpg
photos.title: Titan Triggerfish
photos.description: Scattered throughout the world's seas, the triggerfish is usually a solitary fish. It's territorial and can be nasty to intruders if there are eggs to protect. Be respectful and watch its signals, an erect dorsal spine (on top of the fish) means stay away.

photos.name: DSC00054.jpg
photos.title: Tufted gray langur
photos.description: A female langur and her baby. The offspring stay attached to their mother for the first three months of their lives.

photos.name: DSC03000.jpg
photos.title: Scalloped Hammerhead Shark
photos.description: Hammerheads are often seen in large schools during the day, but at night they feed solitary. The stingray is it's favored prey.

photos.name: DSC03596.jpg
photos.title: Round Ribbontail Ray
photos.description: This type of ray is overfished across much of it's range. However, they thrive around Cocos and we saw them on almost all dives.

photos.name: DSC06038.jpg
photos.title: Dead Man's Fingers
photos.description: Colonies of these soft corals are known to live for over 20 years in the cold northern Atlantic Ocean.

photos.name: DSC04884.jpg
photos.title: White-spotted Hermit Crab
photos.description: A hermit crab's home is the shell of a gastropod, usually snails. As they grow, larger shells are required. However, suitable intact shells are of limited resource and competition for the best shell among hermit crabs is common. If a crab looking for new vacancy finds a shell that is too large, it will stay in its current shell and wait by the vacant shell for other hermit crabs to arrive. As other crabs arrive and check the shell, they will do the same and when finally one finds the vacant shell suitable, each crab exchange shells in sequence.

photos.name: DSC02022.jpg
photos.title: Smooth Trunkfish
photos.description: Using its large mouth, the trunkfish expel a jet of water on the seabed to reveal hidden treats like worms and small crustaceans.

photos.name: DSC03040.jpg
photos.title: Whitetip Reef Shark
photos.description: Whitetips feed at night and their usual shy attitude during daytime disappear completely. You swim with hundreds of sharks when diving at night on Cocos. This dive is one of my all-time favorites.

photos.name: DSC03242.jpg
photos.title: Spotted Eagle Ray
photos.description: The gorgeous eagle rays can grow up to five meters, including a whip-like tail.

photos.name: DSC07841.jpg
photos.title: Bluecheek Butterflyfish
photos.description: Endemic to the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, the bluecheek butterflyfish is one of the few species of fish that have long-term mates.

photos.name: Kris Krister 412.jpg
photos.title: Potato Cod
photos.description: A large, friendly and curious fellow. The potato cods are rare but territorial, thus quite easy to find once located. They seem to chill out at the same place, getting cleaned by wrasses. One of the potato cods on the barrier reef was so large it was nicknamed VW Beetle.
photos.location: Cod Hole, Great Barrier Reef, Australia

photos.name: DSC00974.jpg
photos.title: Garden Eels
photos.description: Sometimes mistaken for swaying seagrass, these small eels live in colonies that can reach over a thousand individuals. Each eel has its own burrow in the sand that it seldom leaves.

photos.name: DSC03470.jpg
photos.title: Mexican Hogfish
photos.description: All Bodianus d. start life as female and later become males.

photos.name: DSC09129.jpg
photos.title: Juvenile Blacktip Reef Shark
photos.description: Patrolling the shallows, half a dozen or so juvenile blacktips are using the safe nursing grounds outside a small beach on the island Perhentian Besar to practice the skill of hunting.

photos.name: DSC03276.jpg
photos.title: Spotted Scorpionfish
photos.description: Skin flaps and feathery fins help this fish to camouflage against the surrounding coral.

photos.name: DSC02484.jpg
photos.title: Klara of Pandan Island
photos.description: On a tiny island just outside Mindoro in the Philippines lives an old parrot named Klara, watched over by the two owners of the island. Over time I learned there was more to the story than just keeping a parrot as a pet. In fact, it's very touching but too long to write here. Ask me one time if you want to hear it.

photos.name: DSC04072.jpg
photos.title: Spottail grunt
photos.description: Longer and thinner than most grunts, the spottail is named after the black botch at the base of the caudal fin.

photos.name: DSC02971.jpg
photos.title: Harlequin Swimming Crab
photos.description: This cool crab, decorated with awesome symmetric spots, is part of a family that, with the help of a pair of broad paddle-like legs, can swim. It's around one centimeter long and can be seen around tube anemones.

photos.name: IMG_3351.jpg
photos.title: The Yucatán Cenotes
photos.description: The eastern parts of Mexico is highly fertile with dense jungle and a magnificent flora. Underground cave systems filled with water act as the area’s principal source of water. For us, access to these underground labyrinths are through sinkholes called cenotes. Diving in the area is otherworldly, a fantastic experience.

photos.name: DSC01178.jpg
photos.title: Shore Diving Bonaire
photos.description: The entire coastline of Bonaire's leeside is fringed by a beautiful coral reef, most of it accessible from shore. The reef starts at about two meter depth, so you could easily stay the entire dive at only a few meters depth if you want.

photos.name: DSC06497.jpg
photos.title: Giant Moray Eel
photos.description: Born as male and turns into female later in life, this eel can grow up to three meters long.

photos.name: DSC02713.jpg
photos.title: Wire Coral Shrimp
photos.description: Lives exclusively on the black coral whip, usually in pairs. I found only one, but they are very well camouflaged and small, so perhaps a second companion was around somewhere. You may wonder why the whip is called black coral when it's bright green, and the reason is due to its black inner skeleton. The outer flesh varies in color and P. Unciger shrimps adapt by changing their own skin to match the coral's color.
